content.value_statement: Create beautiful, unique generative art pieces using p5.js with reproducible seeded randomness, interactive parameter controls, and exportable HTML artifacts.
actual_capabilities: Creates algorithmic philosophies (generative art manifestos) as foundation for implementations
Generates self-contained interactive HTML artifacts with embedded p5.js code
Implements seeded randomness for reproducible art (Art Blocks pattern)
Provides parameter controls with real-time updates via sliders and color pickers
Includes seed navigation (previous/next/random/jump) for exploring variations
Supports various generative techniques: flow fields, particle systems, recursive structures, noise fields
Produces gallery-quality computational art with Anthropic branding
Exports PNG images of generated artwork
Creates animated or static generative compositions
limitations: Requires browser environment to run generated HTML artifacts
Limited to p5.js library capabilities and canvas-based rendering
Performance depends on parameter complexity and particle counts
Does not create raster images directly (generates code that renders art)
Focused on abstract/algorithmic art rather than representational imagery
Cannot recreate specific existing artists' copyrighted styles

best_practices: Always start by creating a clear algorithmic philosophy (4-6 paragraphs) before implementing code
Use seeded randomness (randomSeed/noiseSeed) for reproducible artwork that can be regenerated from the same seed
Read templates/viewer.html first and use it as the literal starting point, keeping fixed sections (layout, branding, seed controls) unchanged
Design parameters that naturally emerge from your algorithm's needs, not from preset pattern menus
Emphasize craftsmanship - make algorithms feel meticulously tuned and refined
Keep all code self-contained in a single HTML artifact with inline JavaScript
Include meaningful parameter controls that let users explore the generative space
Maintain Anthropic branding (colors, fonts, layout) in the UI while making the art itself unique
Test that seed navigation works correctly (same seed always produces identical output)
Optimize performance for smooth rendering, especially with high particle counts
anti_patterns: Creating HTML artifacts from scratch instead of using templates/viewer.html as the foundation
Copying existing artists' copyrighted styles or specific works
Using unseeded randomness that produces non-reproducible results
Making static images with randomness instead of true algorithmic/generative art
Creating separate .js files instead of embedding everything inline in the HTML artifact
Changing Anthropic branding (UI colors, fonts, layout structure) in the viewer template
Adding parameters for their own sake instead of deriving them from algorithmic needs
Writing minimal algorithmic philosophies (1-2 paragraphs) instead of substantial 4-6 paragraph manifestos
Skipping the philosophy creation step and jumping straight to implementation
Treating the generator_template.js as a pattern menu to copy from rather than structural guidance

faq.question: What's the difference between this and just asking Claude to create art?
faq.answer: This skill follows a two-phase process: first creating an algorithmic philosophy (a computational aesthetic manifesto), then implementing it as interactive p5.js code with seeded randomness and parameter controls. It produces self-contained HTML artifacts with professional UI that can be explored, exported, and reproduced deterministically.

faq.question: Do I need to know JavaScript or p5.js to use this?
faq.answer: No coding knowledge required. The skill handles all implementation. You simply describe the aesthetic or concept you want, and it creates both the philosophical framework and the working code.

faq.question: What does 'seeded randomness' mean and why does it matter?
faq.answer: Seeded randomness means each artwork can be perfectly reproduced from its seed number. The same seed always generates identical output. This is crucial for NFTs, archival purposes, and sharing specific variations you discover while exploring.

faq.question: Can I customize the generated art after it's created?
faq.answer: Yes! The HTML artifact includes interactive controls for all key parameters (particle counts, speeds, colors, etc.) and seed navigation to explore infinite variations. You can also edit the HTML file directly to modify the algorithm.

faq.question: What art styles can this create?
faq.answer: It specializes in algorithmic/generative art: flow fields, particle systems, recursive structures, noise patterns, geometric compositions, and emergent behaviors. It creates ORIGINAL algorithmic art, not copies of existing artists' styles.

faq.question: How do I use the generated HTML file?
faq.answer: The HTML file is completely self-contained. You can: 1) View it directly in Claude.ai as an artifact, 2) Save and open it in any web browser, 3) Share the file with others (no server needed), 4) Export PNG images using the built-in download button.

faq.question: What's the 'algorithmic philosophy' and why create it first?
faq.answer: The algorithmic philosophy is a 4-6 paragraph manifesto defining a computational aesthetic movement - how ideas manifest through code, noise, particles, and emergence. Creating it first ensures the final algorithm has conceptual depth and intentionality, not just random visual effects.

faq.question: Can I create multiple variations of the same concept?
faq.answer: Absolutely! Each artwork includes seed navigation (prev/next/random buttons) to explore infinite variations of the same algorithm. You can jump to specific seeds or browse sequentially to find variations you like.
